content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

Here is how you can define the `show` function in Julia:

```julia
struct FloatWithUnits{T<:AbstractFloat}
    value::T
    unit::String
end

function Base.show(io::IO, fwu::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, fwu.value, " ", fwu.unit)
end
```
The `Base.show` function is a built-in function in Julia that prints an object to the console. The first argument is the IO stream (which could be the standard output or any other IO device), and the second argument is the object you want to print. In our case, it's a `FloatWithUnits` instance.

The `io` parameter represents the output of your program. For example, if you call `println(fwu)`, where `fwu` is an instance of `FloatWithUnits`, this will print "1.8 meters" to the console.
